{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3487331,"name":"Jacob","username":"JDM2024","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/7bcc69/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-19T05:33:06.179Z","cooked":"

Hi! My team recently bought swerve drive components for the first time in our clubs history, so this will be our first year not using tank drive.

Last year, our team used spark max motor controllers to operate our robot. We paired these with Neo motors. It was very nice that all of the encoder functionality was built in. We bought 4 CTRE swerve modules, and after doing a research On how to code these modules, I am worried that Our motor control controllers Are not compatible with the swerve module.

I understand that we might not be able to use the CTRE Swerve Project Generator API, And I have not found other resources that show me how to use a CTRE Swerve module with Spark max Motor controllers. Is there anyone that could help with this?

Obviously, we are brand new to swerve drive, but our coders are also newer to FRC coding. Any help would be greatly appreciated to help us cut down the learning curve! Thank you!

If they are the WCP modules, you should be able to set up a swerve drive using YAGSL. There is a bit of a learning curve at first, but the features they offer are quite nice.

I’m sure it depends on which modules you got but I just went with the first link it gave me when I looked up CTRE swerve modules.

CTR Electronics

WCP Swerve X Module (Flipped)

This generation of the swerve drive module was designed from the ground up to utilize the powerful Kraken X60 brushless motor to improve performance and remove complexity. This design is smaller than our previous designs, is more versatile...

Price: USD 324.98

This module specifically says “Accepts 550, 775, CIM, Neo, & Kraken X60”
So yes, Neos would be fine.

The CTRE swerve generator is strictly limited to teams who use all ctre motors, and gyro, so you wouldn’t be able to use it. However like what @Maroon_Golf said there is YAGSL which is another easier-ish solution to swerve drive.
